threads.com:
This board is dedicated to the discussion of history and the other humanities such as philosophy, religion, law, classical artwork, archeology, anthropology, ancient languages, etc. Please use /lit/ for discussions of literature. Threads should be about specific topics, and the creation of "general" threads is discouraged.

For the purpose of determining what is history, please do not start threads about events taking place less than 25 years ago. Historical discussions should be focused on past events, and not their contemporary consequences. Discussion of modern politics, current events, popular culture, or other non-historical topics should be posted elsewhere. General discussions about international culture should go on /int/.

/his/ is not /pol/, and Global Rule #3 is in effect. Do not try to treat this board as /pol/ with dates. Blatant racism and trolling will not be tolerated, and a high level of discourse is expected. History can be examined from many different conflicting viewpoints; please treat other posters with respect and address the content of their post instead of attacking their character.

When discussing history, please reference credible source material, and provide as much supporting information as possible in your posts.

People who make racism into this thing where it's about calling people out as a racist, and turning it into a sort of label for specific people actually end up diluting the usefulness of the idea of racism as the reality most if not all people hold racist ideas to varying degrees.

Our Current society has racist ideas at it's foundation , most of the important historical events are informed by racial and nationalist ideas, and likewise we as people are always going to be learning about and thinking about race. Wether your black, white, asian or any race with access to modern society, you're going to have internalized racist ideas and are going to be able to at the very least read situations from race based frameworks.

So making the conversation about calling people out as racist is sort of redundant, as you essentially have to be extremely racist or hateful to get the label and it stops even being about being racist and just about being hateful. Really we should focus on thinking about Racist actions and Racist Ideas, and rather then calling people out as racist and asking them to prove they are not racist, it should calling them out on their racist actions and asking them to explain their rational and intentions behind the actions.

Everything person is capable of doing racist acts, no matter their race, so it should be more so about just educating and being aware of racism and how it can inform our actions.

>Asanuma graduated from Waseda University in 1923 with a degree in political science and economics. last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Native use of the land is extremely population-inefficient. A native population center in the low hundreds of people requires a massive acreage to support itself because they are completely dependent on seasonal migrations.It's not just the land in the immediate vicinity which they hunt, it's also the ring of lands neighboring this territory, which are a kind of "buffer" between neighboring tribes, deliberately left alone so that wild game can congregate there after they have been hunted out of their core territories. Then the natives will gradually move into these buffer areas while the old areas recover.

It's definitely sustainable, it's just not going to support a very large population. Hence why these semi-sedentary tribes never got very populous.

You did see much larger settlements, with thousands or tens of thousands, but these were more sedentary, agricultural peoples, and most of them did not survive to see European contact.

The "Red Summer" of 1919 was a violent one marred by major disorders across American cities including several large-scale race riots. In Charleston, South Carolina on May 10, an argument started at a pool hall on Beaufain & Charles Street between several white Navy sailors and a black patron whom the former believed cheated them at a pool game. The black patron managed to escape into the streets and the sailors, unable to find him, took out their anger on random blacks in the streets. The riot escalated and soon over 1,000 sailors from the Charleston Naval Yard and some civilians joined in.

Blacks were grabbed, beaten, and shot at at random. Admiral Frank Beatty dispatched Marines to clear the riots along with the help of local police. By 2:30 AM order had been restored. A total of 5 blacks were killed and one later succumbed to his injuries. Multiple other blacks, white sailors, and at least one police officer were injured and numerous black stores and homes were looted and vandalized. Three sailors were court-martialed; one was acquitted and the two others were given a year imprisonment, followed by dishonorable discharge. Eight civilians were fined $50 each for carrying concealed weapons.

The Charleston Evening Post blamed the riots on sailors who were not from the segregated South and consequently unfamiliar with its social codes. It also insisted that the racial situation in the city had always been a harmonious one.

Well, the helmet isn't actually horned, Odin's birds, Thought and Memory, are on his head. You can just look at the depiction there: they aren't horns, they're birds. last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>14231475
You struggle to find phonetic equivalents to ź, ś, and ć because there are none. How they sound is hard to explain in layman's terms without getting into professinally-sounding tongue positions and IPA, but I'll try anyway
ś is very similar to sz, it just sounds less "heavy." Try pronouncing "sh" first, you'll notice that you're pressing the tip of your tongue on a very specific spot on your palate. If, instead of pressing only the tip, you press the base of your tongue, you'll be able to pronounce ś. It requires practice.
ź is a voiced version of ś, just like ż/rz (second g in garage) is a voiced version of sz (sh) and dż is a voiced version of cz.
ć to cz is like ś to sz. Same places of pronunciation, even: cz - tip, ć - base. The only difference is that ś/sz is a fricative (continuous sound through an obstruction) and ć/cz is a plosive (one sudden sound).
Bonus phoneme: dź is a voiced version of ć

The Far Eastern Republic (Russian: Дaльнeвocтóчнaя Pecпýбликa, ДBP, tr. Although theoretically independent, it largely came under the control of the Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic (RSFSR), which envisaged it as a buffer state between the RSFSR and the territories occupied by Japan during the Russian Civil War of 1917–1922.
